para.p:
Let
( Ω , Σ , μ )
be a probability space. For
∈
A , B
Σ
, define

Math.text: d _ mu * open-interval@(A, B) = mu * A * triangle * B

para.p:
This is a pseduometric on
Σ
:

Math.text: d _ mu * open-interval@(A, C) = mu * A * triangle * C
d _ mu * open-interval@(A, C)
absent = mu * A * triangle * C
absent = mu * A * triangle * B * triangle * B * triangle * C
absent = mu * A * triangle * B * triangle * B * triangle * C
absent less= mu * (A * triangle * B union B * triangle * C)
absent less= mu * (A * triangle * B union B * triangle * C)
absent less= mu * A * triangle * B + mu * B * triangle * C
absent less= mu * A * triangle * B + mu * B * triangle * C
absent = d _ mu * open-interval@(A, B) + d _ mu * open-interval@(B, C)
absent = d _ mu * open-interval@(A, B) + d _ mu * open-interval@(B, C)

para.p:
The relation
∼ A B
if and only if
=
⁢
d μ
( A , B )
0
is an equivalence relation on
Σ
, and
=
⁢
d μ
(
[ A ]
,
[ B ]
)
⁢
d μ
( A , B )
is a metric on the collection
Σ μ
of equivalence classes. We call
d μ
the symmetric difference metric.

The following theorem shows that
(
Σ μ
,
d μ
)
is a complete metric space. 1 1 footnote 1 V. I. Bogachev, Measure Theory, volume I, p. 54, Theorem 1.12.16.

p.text:
If
( Ω , Σ , μ )
is a probability space, then
(
Σ μ
,
d μ
)
is a complete metric space.

para.p:
Suppose that
[
B n
]
is a Cauchy sequence in
(
Σ μ
,
d μ
)
. As for any Cauchy sequence in a metric space, there is a subsequence
[
A n
]
of
[
B n
]
such that
<
⁢
d μ
(
[
A k
]
,
[
A n
]
)
2
- n
for
≥ k n
. Define

Math.text: E _ n = (union _ (k >= n))@(A _ k)
E _ n set-minus A _ n = ((union _ (k = n + 1)) ^ infinity)@(A _ k set-minus A _ n)
E _ n set-minus A _ n
absent = ((union _ (k = n + 1)) ^ infinity)@(A _ k set-minus A _ n)
absent = (union _ (k = n + 1))@(A _ k set-minus ((union _ (j = n)) ^ (k - 1))@(A _ j))
absent = (union _ (k = n + 1))@(A _ k set-minus ((union _ (j = n)) ^ (k - 1))@(A _ j))
absent subset-of (union _ (k = n + 1))@(A _ k set-minus A _ (k - 1))
absent subset-of (union _ (k = n + 1))@(A _ k set-minus A _ (k - 1))
absent = ((union _ (k = n)) ^ infinity)@(A _ (k + 1) set-minus A _ k)
absent = ((union _ (k = n)) ^ infinity)@(A _ (k + 1) set-minus A _ k)
mu * E _ n * triangle * A _ n = mu * (E _ n set-minus A _ n) less= ((sum _ (k = n)) ^ infinity)@(mu * (A _ (k + 1) set-minus A _ k)) less ((sum _ (k = n)) ^ infinity)@(2 ^ (- k)) = 2 ^ ((- n) + 1)
A = (limit-supremum _ (n to infinity))@(A _ n) = ((intersection _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(((union _ (k = n)) ^ infinity)@(A _ k)) = ((intersection _ (n = 1)) ^ infinity)@(E _ n)
mu * A _ n * triangle * A = mu * (A _ n set-minus A)
mu * A _ n * triangle * A
absent = mu * (A _ n set-minus A)
absent = mu * (A _ n intersection (((intersection _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(E _ k)) ^ c)
absent = mu * (A _ n intersection (((intersection _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(E _ k)) ^ c)
absent = mu * (A _ n intersection ((union _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@((E _ k) ^ c))
absent = mu * (A _ n intersection ((union _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@((E _ k) ^ c))
absent = mu * ((union _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(A _ n intersection (E _ k) ^ c)
absent = mu * ((union _ (k = 1)) ^ infinity)@(A _ n intersection (E _ k) ^ c)
absent = (limit _ (k to infinity))@(mu * (A _ n intersection (E _ k) ^ c))
absent = (limit _ (k to infinity))@(mu * (A _ n intersection (E _ k) ^ c))
absent = (limit _ (k to infinity))@(mu * (intersection _ (j >= k))@(A _ n set-minus A _ j))
absent = (limit _ (k to infinity))@(mu * (intersection _ (j >= k))@(A _ n set-minus A _ j))
absent less= (limit _ (k to infinity))@(mu * (A _ n set-minus A _ k))
absent less= (limit _ (k to infinity))@(mu * (A _ n set-minus A _ k))
absent less 2 ^ (- n)
absent less 2 ^ (- n)
d _ mu * open-interval@(A _ n, A) less= mu * E _ n * triangle * A _ n + mu * A _ n * triangle * A less 2 ^ ((- n) + 1) + 2 ^ (- n) = 3 cdot 2 ^ (- n)

para.p:
showing that
[
A n
]
converges to
[ A ]
as
→ n ∞
, and because
[
A n
]
is a subsequence of the Cauchy sequence
[
B n
]
, it follows that
[
B n
]
converges to
[ A ]
and therefore that
(
Σ μ
,
d μ
)
is a complete metric space. ∎

Math.text: absolute-value@(mu * A - mu * B) less= mu * A * triangle * B
absolute-value@(mu * A - mu * B) = absolute-value@((mu * (A set-minus B) + mu * (A intersection B)) - (mu * (B set-minus A) + mu * (B intersection B)))
absolute-value@(mu * A - mu * B)
absent = absolute-value@((mu * (A set-minus B) + mu * (A intersection B)) - (mu * (B set-minus A) + mu * (B intersection B)))
absent = absolute-value@(mu * (A set-minus B) - mu * (B set-minus A))
absent = absolute-value@(mu * (A set-minus B) - mu * (B set-minus A))
absent less= mu * (A set-minus B) + mu * (B set-minus A)
absent less= mu * (A set-minus B) + mu * (B set-minus A)
absent = mu * ((A set-minus B) union (B set-minus A))
absent = mu * ((A set-minus B) union (B set-minus A))
absent less= mu * A * triangle * B
absent less= mu * A * triangle * B

para.p:
The following theorem connects the metric space
(
Σ μ
,
d μ
)
with the Banach space
⁢
L 1
( μ )
. 2 2 footnote 2 John B. Conway, A Course in Abstract Analysis, p. 90, Proposition 2.7.13.

p.text:
If
(
Σ μ
,
d μ
)
is separable then
⁢
L 1
( μ )
is separable.
